newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: China to remain net copper importer long-term.
newsitem.headline: China to remain net copper importer long-term.

text.p: China will continue to import copper in the long-term because local output lags demand, the deputy general-manger of the China National Non-ferrous Metals Import and Export Corporation (CNIEC) said on Tuesday.
"China will still buy large quantities of copper from the international market so as to make up the domestic shortage," Zhang Yisheng said at a copper conference in Singapore.
He quoted customs statistics as showing that copper imports reached around 851,700 tonnes in 1996 from 601,700 tonnes in 1995.
"The growth rate of copper consumption in China in the next five years will maintain an average rate of 13 percent. By the year 2000, copper consumption will exceed 1.8 million tonnes," Zhang said.
"However, the prospects of China seem good from the point of view of resources," Zhang said.
Proven copper reserves currently stand at more than 60 million tonnes, with only half of them having been developed.
The main end-user of copper in China is the power sector, followed by the light industry, machine and transport sector. Airconditoners alone need around 30,000 tonnes of copper per year, he said.
